item.title: Shanghai explainer on taxation of digital currency transaction drives speculation on potential easing of China’s crypto ban
item.description:
English summary：

On Sunday, an explainer article regarding tax on cryptocurrency activities in China was shared widely after it emerged on the Shanghai Municipal Tax Service WeChat account. The article, which was later removed, cited a 2008 statement by the State Taxation Administration (STA) and discussed taxation of income earned from virtual currency transactions. Some crypto enthusiasts interpreted this as a potential easing of the strict cryptocurrency ban imposed by China. However, legal experts clarified that the article does not indicate a policy shift, emphasizing that it merely addressed online payments of video game tokens. This news stirs speculation and debate among the Chinese crypto community and cues a desire for a comprehensive Web3 development plan. Although China remains officially opposed to cryptocurrency, regulatory oversight of虚拟资产related income taxation might grow.
  • Abstract: Speculation arises in the Chinese crypto community after Shanghai's tax service article on cryptocurrency taxation, even though China's anti-crypto stance is firm.
  • Theme: An article posted by Shanghai Municipal Tax Service discussing cryptocurrency transaction taxation prompts speculation of a potential shift in China's cryptocurrency policy.
  • Viewpoint: Varied interpretations of the article; enthusiasts see easing of crypto ban while experts emphasize its limited scope to video game tokens; speculation in Chinese crypto circles amidst Web3 aspirations.
  • Main information: Article's removal from Shanghai tax service's WeChat account; clarification by legal experts; discussions of Web3 development plan; China's opposition to cryptocurrencies.

中文总结：

周日，一篇有关中国对加密货币活动征税的解释文章在上海市税务局微信公众号发布后被广泛传播。这篇文章后来被删除，引用了国家税务局2008年的一份声明，讨论了从虚拟货币交易中获得的收入的税收问题。一些加密货币爱好者将此解读为对中国实施的严格加密货币禁令的潜在放松。然而，法律专家澄清说，这篇文章并不意味着政策的转变，强调它只是解决了视频游戏代币的在线支付问题。这一消息在中国的加密货币圈内引起了猜测和争论，并暗示了人们希望制定全面的Web3发展计划。虽然中国仍然正式反对加密货币，但对于虚拟资产相关收入征税的监管可能会加强。
  • 摘要：尽管中国对加密货币持反对态度，但上海税务局关于加密货币税收的文章引发了中国加密货币社区的猜测。
  • 主题：上海市税务局发布文章讨论加密货币交易税收，引发了中国加密货币政策可能转变的猜测。
  • 观点：文章的不同解读；爱好者认为加密货币禁令有所放松，而专家则强调其范围仅限于视频游戏代币；中国加密货币圈内在Web3愿景的背景下产生猜测。
  • 主要信息：文章从上海税务局微信公众号中删除；法律专家的澄清；关于Web3发展计划的讨论；中国反对加密货币。

单词：

  • enthus iasts (n.) - /ɪnˈθjuːzɪæst/ 爱好者，狂热者，热衷者。

    原文例句：Some local crypto enthusiasts suggested that it acknowledged cryptocurrencies’ legitimacy.

    例句讲解：这个单词是由en-（使……成为）和thusia（狂热，热情）构成的，表示“爱好者，狂热者，热衷者”。在这个例句中，它指的是一些当地的加密货币爱好者认为这篇文章承认了加密货币的合法性。

  • speculation (n.) - /spekjuˈleɪʃən/ 推测，臆测，猜测。

    原文例句：The explainer became widely circulated on Sunday after some local crypto enthusiasts suggested that it acknowledged cryptocurrencies’ legitimacy.

    例句讲解：这个单词来源于Latin，由specere（观察）和-tion（行为，动作）构成的，表示“推测，臆测，猜测，意见”。在这个例句中，它指的是一些当地的加密货币爱好者认为这篇文章承认了加密货币的合法性，引起了广泛的猜测。

  • rigid (adj.) - /ˈrɪdʒɪd/ 严格的，僵硬的，死板的，不灵活的。

    原文例句：China over the years has ramped up its crackdown on all activities related to cryptocurrencies, citing financial stability risks.

    例句讲解：这个单词来源于Latin，由rigere（僵硬）构成的，表示“严格的，僵硬的，死板的，不灵活的”。在这个例句中，它指的是中国多年来一直加大力度打击所有与加密货币相关的活动，理由是存在金融稳定风险。

词组：

  • ramp up (v.) - /ræmp ʌp/ 加强，加大，提高，增加，膨胀。

    原文例句：China over the years has ramped up its crackdown on all activities related to cryptocurrencies, citing financial stability risks.

    例句讲解：这个词组是由ramp（斜坡，坡道）和up（向上）构成的，表示“加强，加大，提高，增加，膨胀”。在这个例句中，它指的是中国多年来一直加大力度打击所有与加密货币相关的活动。

句子：

  • The explainer became widely circulated on Sunday after some local crypto enthusiasts suggested that it acknowledged cryptocurrencies’ legitimacy - 这名解释者在一些当地加密货币爱好者建议它承认了加密货币的合法性之后，于周日被广泛传播。

    句子分析：这是一个复合句，主句是The explainer became widely circulated，其中主语是The explainer，谓语是became widely circulated，宾语是后置宾语after some local crypto enthusiasts suggested that it acknowledged cryptocurrencies’ legitimacy。after some local crypto enthusiasts suggested that it acknowledged cryptocurrencies’ legitimacy是一个过去分词短语作状语，修饰The explainer，表示这一消息是在一些当地加密货币爱好者建议它承认了加密货币的合法性之后。这个句子的意思是说，这一消息在一些当地加密货币爱好者建议它承认了加密货币的合法性之后，于周日被广泛传播。

语法：

  • 现在完成时 - 表示从过去某个时间开始一直持续到现在的动作或状态。

    原文例句：China over the years has ramped up its crackdown on all activities related to cryptocurrencies, citing financial stability risks.

    语法讲解：这是一种时态，结构是：have/has + been + 现在分词。其中have/has要根据主语的人称和数进行变化，been是be的过去分词，现在分词是动词的-ing形式。这种时态表示动作或状态从过去某个时间开始一直持续到现在，强调动作或状态的持续性和未完成性。在这个例句中，它表示中国多年来一直加大力度打击所有与加密货币相关的活动，直到现在仍在进行。

  • The explainer became widely circulated on Sunday after some local crypto enthusiasts suggested that it acknowledged cryptocurrencies’ legitimacy
  • The Shanghai Municipal Tax Service has since deleted the article from its public WeChat account

An online article posted by the Shanghai Municipal Tax Service, explaining levies imposed on digital currency transactions in China, has fanned speculation among local cryptocurrency enthusiasts that it signals a potential relaxation of the country’s draconian ban on crypto operations.

The explainer, “Common Misunderstandings Regarding Personal Income Tax on Business Income and Categorised Income”, became widely circulated on Sunday after it was published on WeChat by the Shanghai tax service on Thursday. It cited a 2008 statement by the State Taxation Administration (STA).

That prompted some crypto-themed online content creators on the mainland to suggest that taxing such transactions show authorities are starting to acknowledge the legitimacy of cryptocurrencies. The Shanghai tax service subsequently deleted the explainer on Sunday from its public WeChat account.

The wide attention received by the Shanghai tax service’s explainer reflects the lingering hope among Chinese crypto circles that the country’s rigid ban on cryptocurrencies would be reviewed amid Beijing’s drive to expand adoption of the digital yuan.

China’s Ministry of Industry and Information Technology last month announced plans to draft a national Web3 development plan to suit the country’s needs, although it did not specifically mention cryptocurrencies.

Mainland legal experts, however, pointed out that the Shanghai tax service’s explainer does not suggest any potential change in the country’s cryptocurrency policy.

The published article is not an official policy document, and the STA statement it cited concerns virtual tokens used in video games, according to Guo Zhihao, a partner at Beijing-based Yingke Law Firm, in an article he posted on WeChat on Sunday.

The explainer had indicated that individuals who obtain virtual currencies from other players through online transactions and generate revenue by selling them at a higher price must pay income tax on such earnings. The Shanghai tax agency’s article detailed taxation in four scenarios, including loans obtained by individual investors from their investee companies and online monetary gifts.

Chinese economist calls for review of rigid crypto ban amid slow e-CNY adoption

China over the years has ramped up its crackdown on all activities related to cryptocurrencies, citing financial stability risks. It maintains that stance even though it supports Hong Kong’s ambitions to become a major hub for virtual assets, including cryptocurrencies.

While there is no official sign from Beijing about changing its position on cryptocurrencies, local crypto circles expect increased regulatory oversight on the taxation of virtual asset-related income on the mainland.

China has denied legal-tender status for cryptocurrencies, but has not opposed its attribution as property or commodity, according to an article published on Friday by Jin Jianzhi of the Shanghai Mankun Law Firm. The lawyer said the government can levy taxes on relevant transactions under the law.

The global cryptocurrency market, meanwhile, appears to be slowly recovering from a prolonged slump last year. Bitcoin prices gained more than 150 per cent from a year earlier on the back of expectations that the US Securities and Exchange Commission will soon approve bitcoin exchange-traded funds, which would make these virtual assets more attractive to mainstream investors.

item.title: CES 2024: Chinese tech giants Alibaba, ByteDance lead China’s return to premier consumer electronics show in Las Vegas
item.description:
English summary：

  • Chinese companies are returning to CES in large numbers, showcasing their latest technologies and products.
  • Artificial intelligence is expected to be the major trend at the show, with many companies touting their use of AI in their products.
  • Despite geopolitical tensions, US and Chinese companies are still eager to do business with each other.
  • CES remains the premier event for technology companies to showcase their latest innovations.

中文总结：

  • 中国公司大举回归CES，展示其最新的技术和产品。
  • 预计人工智能将成为展会上的主要趋势，许多公司都在宣传其在产品中使用人工智能。
  • 尽管存在地缘政治紧张局势，美国和中国公司仍然渴望开展业务合作。
  • CES仍然是科技公司展示其最新创新的首要活动。

单词：

  • touting (v.) - 大肆宣传，张扬。

    原文例句：The return of Chinese tech giants comes even as geopolitical tensions have barely budged from where they were last year.

    例句讲解：这个单词是由tout（吹嘘，夸耀）构成的，表示“大肆宣传，张扬”。在这个例句中，它指的是中国科技巨头的回归，即使地缘政治紧张局势几乎没有从去年的情况发生变化。

  • attendance (n.) - 出勤，参加，出席人数。

    原文例句：Kelley said CES expects to see 130,000 attendees.

    例句讲解：这个单词是由attend（参加）构成的，表示“出勤，参加，出席人数”。在这个例句中，它指的是CES预计会有130,000名与会者。

  • generative (adj.) - 生成式的，创造性的。

    原文例句：Smart homes, green tech and electric vehicles were other areas highlighted during the show’s opening remarks to the media.

    例句讲解：这个单词是由generate（产生）构成的，表示“生成式的，创造性的”。在这个例句中，它指的是智能家居、绿色科技和电动汽车等领域也是在展会开幕时向媒体重点介绍的领域。

词组：

  • make up - 构成，组成，占……比例。

    原文例句：It remains the premier event of its kind.

    例句讲解：这个词组是由make（制作）和up（组成）构成的，表示“构成，组成，占……比例”。在这个例句中，它指的是CES仍然是同类活动中的首要盛会。

  • showcase (v.) - 展示，陈列。

    原文例句：Xpeng is showcasing its AeroHT flying car at CES 2024.

    例句讲解：这个词组是由show（展示）和case（情况）构成的，表示“展示，陈列”。在这个例句中，它指的是小鹏汽车在CES 2024上展示其AeroHT飞行汽车。

句子：

  • Artificial intelligence (AI) is expected to be the major trend at the show this year, playing an even larger role since ChatGPT ignited a generative AI arms race over the past year.

    句子分析：这是一个复合句，主句是Artificial intelligence (AI) is expected to be the major trend at the show this year，其中主语是Artificial intelligence (AI)，谓语是expected to be，宾语是the major trend at the show this year。playing an even larger role since ChatGPT ignited a generative AI arms race over the past year是一个现在分词短语作状语，表示人工智能自ChatGPT在过去一年引发了生成式人工智能军备竞赛以来，发挥了更大的作用。这个句子的意思是说，人工智能预计将成为今年展会上的主要趋势，自ChatGPT在过去一年引发了生成式人工智能军备竞赛以来，发挥了更大的作用。

语法：

  • 过去完成时 - 表示在过去某个时间之前已经发生或完成的动作或状态。

    原文例句：Shenzhen-based smart lighting company Govee is integrating generative AI to allow users to create specific moods.

    语法讲解：这是一种时态，结构是：had + been + 过去分词。其中had要根据主语的人称和数进行变化，been是be的过去分词，过去分词是动词的-ed形式。这种时态表示动作或状态在过去某个时间之前已经发生或完成，强调动作或状态的完成性。在这个例句中，它表示深圳智能照明公司Govee正在整合生成式人工智能，以使用户能够创造特定的氛围。

  • 虚拟语气 - 表示假设、愿望、建议、命令或请求。

    原文例句：“We like to make the case that the four days you spend in Las Vegas is some of the most efficient use of your time in the sense that you don’t have to necessarily travel the world to meet with individual business partners on six different continents,” said Kelley.

    语法讲解：这是一种语气，表示假设、愿望、建议、命令或请求。它的结构通常是：should + 动词原形，或would + 动词原形。在这个例句中，it表示凯利说：“我们想说明的是，你们在拉斯维加斯度过的四天时间是最有效率的，因为你们不一定需要环游世界，就可以在六大洲与各个商业伙伴会面”。

  • AI is the major trend this year in the wake of ChatGPT, with many companies touting how they are integrating the tech into their products
  • The return of Chinese tech giants comes even as geopolitical tensions have barely budged from where they were last year

Chinese companies have returned to Las Vegas for CES in full force this year, with more than double the number of exhibitors compared with last year, including big names like ByteDance and Alibaba.com, as companies try to shake off Covid-era blues with overseas growth.

CES lists 1,115 companies registered from China on its website, a 126 per cent increase over the 493 listed at the beginning of the 2023 show. That does not include many of the biggest names on the list, which joined using international addresses.

ByteDance and its subsidiary TikTok, along with big hardware brands from last year like TCL and Lenovo are registered under their US offices. Even Alibaba Group Holding, owner of the South China Morning Post, has a presence through its subsidiary Alibaba.com Singapore.

TikTok eyes US$17.5 billion shopping business on Amazon’s turf

“You have big exhibitors coming back, really showcasing that this is a platform that really pushes for consumers and enterprises and maybe [can] combat some of these major challenges that we’re facing,” Brian Comiskey, director of consumer programmes at the CTA, said after his opening remarks on Sunday afternoon.

This marks a stark reversal from 2023, when China had just started to reopen its borders but restrictions did not fall fast enough for many companies to make it to the show in the first week of January.

“Some of the largest Chinese companies that have signed up for participation this year … will all have a large presence at the show,” John Kelley, vice-president and show director for CES at the Consumer Technology Association (CTA), told the Post in an interview on November 29. “But where we’re really seeing growth on the Chinese side is smaller companies.”

Kelley said the CTA was anticipating numbers to reach pre-Covid levels, and it looks like the show has pulled it off. The number of Chinese companies is more than the 1,000 that state-run tabloid Global Times reported for the 2020 show. CTA said the show has attracted around 4,000 exhibitors, although numbers are not final yet. Kelley said CES expects to see 130,000 attendees.

Artificial intelligence (AI) is expected to be the major trend at the show this year, playing an even larger role since ChatGPT ignited a generative AI arms race over the past year. Smart homes, green tech and electric vehicles were other areas highlighted during the show’s opening remarks to the media.

Alibaba was highlighted as one of the exhibitors using machine learning platforms to “power e-commerce”.

Even much smaller companies are touting their use of AI. Govee, a smart lighting maker from Shenzhen, is advertising the use of generative AI to help people create specific moods, like asking for a backdrop that is evocative of the Hong Kong skyline or Barbie Dreamhouse.

Some fabless chip design firms are also exhibiting, such as Fuzhou-based mobile chip maker Rockchip and Wuhan-based autonomous driving chip maker Black Sesame, which contracts with electric car companies Geely and BYD. Black Sesame chips are manufactured by Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co, it said.

Xpeng is among the major electric vehicle makers at the show, where it will be demonstrating its new “flying car”, the AeroHT.

The return of Chinese tech giants comes even as geopolitical tensions have barely budged from where they were last year. US President Joe Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping may have met in November, but there have been no major policy shifts around escalating restrictions on technology such as semiconductors and AI.

TikTok and its Beijing-based owner ByteDance have been under intense political scrutiny in Washington over data privacy and national security concerns. This may not have deterred TikTok from showing up to the largest consumer electronics shows in its largest market.

Number of Chinese tech firms at CES 2023 less than half of pre-pandemic level

Representatives from the company will join two panels at the show to discuss sports and entertainment. Beyond entertainment, though, ByteDance makes much of its money through advertising and has been trying to grow its e-commerce business.

Other Chinese companies cannot exhibit at the show even if they want to because they have been listed on Washington’s Entity List. This includes the world’s largest drone maker DJI and a number of semiconductor companies.

“From a show management perspective, we welcome participation from every company,” CTA’s Kelley said. “As a US-based trade association, we cannot allow participation if they are on some sort of Entity List. That’s really the only place where we will not allow participation.”

Still, CES may be more important for the many small firms that make up the bulk of the show’s exhibition floor. It remains the premier event of its kind.

“We like to make the case that the four days you spend in Las Vegas is some of the most efficient use of your time in the sense that you don’t have to necessarily travel the world to meet with individual business partners on six different continents,” said Kelley. “Instead, you can come to Las Vegas and meet everybody that you need to meet from the global technology industry over the course of a week.”

item.title: Samsung set for smallest profit drop in 6 quarters on chip rebound
item.description:
English Summary:

  • Samsung Electronics' profits are projected to decline by 14% in Q4, reaching $2.82 billion.
  • Revenue from chips, smartphones, and TVs is expected to decrease, with the chip division witnessing a reduced loss of 1.2 trillion won.
  • Consumer gadget demand woes led to a chip industry downturn, but recent price rebounds signal recovery.
  • Samsung increased silicon wafer procurement while reducing inventory, indicating plans for future DRAM production.
  • Analysts predict a positive outlook for Samsung's mobile business though foldable model shipments saw a dip.

Chinese Summary:

  • 三星电子预计第四季度利润将下降14%，达到28.2亿美元。
  • 来自芯片、智能手机和电视的收入预计将下降，芯片部门的亏损减少至1.2万亿韩元。
  • 消费电子设备需求不振导致芯片行业低迷，但最近价格反弹预示着复苏。
  • 三星增加了硅片的采购，同时减少了库存，表明该公司计划在未来增加DRAM芯片的生产。
  • 分析师预测三星的移动业务将表现良好，尽管可折叠机型出货量有所下降。

Words:

  • rebound (n.) - /ˈriːbaʊnd/ 反弹，复苏。

    原文例句：A solid set of results would justify Samsung’s sharp stock market run-up in the fourth quarter, which has made it Asia’s second-most valuable listed company after Taiwanese rival TSMC, with a market capitalisation of about US$390 billion.

    例句讲解：这个单词来源于Old French，意思是“反弹，回升”。在这个例句中，它指三星在第四季度股市的快速反弹。

  • inventory (n.) - /ˈɪnvəntori/ 库存，存货。

    原文例句：Samsung was also more aggressive in selling memory chips than competitors such as SK Hynix in the fourth quarter in a bid to lower inventory, analysts said.

    例句讲解：这个单词来源于Medieval Latin，意思是“清单，目录”。在这个例句中，它指的是三星在第四季度比竞争对手SK Hynix更积极地出售内存芯片，以降低库存。

Phrases:

  • quarter-on-quarter (adv.) - 环比。

    原文例句：Samsung last reported a year-on-year quarterly profit increase for the second quarter of 2022.

    例句讲解：这个词组是由quarter（季度）和on-quarter（环比）组成的，意思是“环比”。在这个例句中，它表示三星上次报告同比季度利润增长是在2022年第二季度。

  • market capitalisation (n.) - 市值。

    原文例句：A solid set of results would justify Samsung’s sharp stock market run-up in the fourth quarter, which has made it Asia’s second-most valuable listed company after Taiwanese rival TSMC, with a market capitalisation of about US$390 billion.

    例句讲解：这个词组是由market（市场）和capitalisation（资本化）组成的，意思是“市值”。在这个例句中，它表示三星的市值约为3900亿美元，是亚洲第二有价值的上市公司。

Sentences:

  • Analysts said its Dynamic Random Access Memory (DRAM) chips business returned to a profit.

    • 句子分析：这是一个复合句，主句是DRAM chips business returned to a profit，其中主语是DRAM chips business，谓语是returned to a profit。Analysts said是一个过去分词短语作状语，修饰主句，表示分析师说。这个句子的意思是说，分析师说三星的动态随机存取内存芯片业务恢复了盈利。

Grammar:

  • 虚拟语气 - 表示假设或希望的情况。

    原文例句：If you do a good job I'll tip you $2000

    语法讲解：这是一个虚拟条件句，类型是第一类虚拟条件句，表示如果达到某个条件，就会产生某种结果。在这个例句中，条件是“如果你做得很好”，结果是“我会给你2000美元的小费”。这个句子的意思是说，如果你做得很好，我会给你2000美元的小费。

  • 被动语态 - 表示动作或状态是由句子中的宾语承受的。

    原文例句：Samsung’s mobile business likely saw an operating profit of around 2.5 trillion won, according to an average of forecasts from eight analysts, as shipments of its two flagship foldable models were estimated to have fallen about 1 million units each versus the third quarter.

    语法讲解：这是一个被动语态的句子，其中主语是operating profit，谓语是被动语态动词saw，宾语是2.5 trillion won。as shipments of its two flagship foldable models were estimated to have fallen about 1 million units each versus the third quarter是一个现在完成时态的分词短语作状语，修饰主句，表示三星的两款旗舰折叠机型的出货量据估计比第三季度减少了约100万台。这个句子的意思是说，三星的手机业务的运营利润可能约为2.5万亿韩元，因为据估计，其两款旗舰折叠机型的出货量与第三季度相比下降了约100万台。

  • The world’s biggest maker of memory chips, smartphones and televisions is expected to show a 14 per cent fall in fourth-quarter profit
  • Samsung’s chip division likely reduced its quarterly loss to around 1.2 trillion won, according to an average of eight forecasts

Samsung Electronics is expected to report its smallest profit drop in six quarters, analysts estimate, as a rebound in semiconductor prices shrinks losses in the South Korean company’s mainstay chip division.

The world’s biggest maker of memory chips, smartphones and televisions is expected to show a 14 per cent fall in fourth-quarter profit when it announces preliminary earnings on Tuesday.

Operating profit likely fell to 3.7 trillion won (US$2.82 billion) in the October-December quarter, according to the average of an LSEG SmartEstimate from 30 analysts, weighted toward those who are more consistently accurate.

US to gather chip supply chain intelligence to boost national security

That would compare with an operating profit of 4.31 trillion won in the December quarter of the previous year. Samsung last reported a year-on-year quarterly profit increase for the second quarter of 2022.

A solid set of results would justify Samsung’s sharp stock market run-up in the fourth quarter, which has made it Asia’s second-most valuable listed company after Taiwanese rival TSMC, with a market capitalisation of about US$390 billion.

Samsung’s chip division – traditionally its biggest earner – likely reduced its quarterly loss to around 1.2 trillion won, according to an average of eight forecasts. Analysts said its Dynamic Random Access Memory (DRAM) chips business returned to a profit.

Samsung had reported chip division losses of 4.36 trillion won and 3.75 trillion won in the second and third quarters, respectively, as a chip glut from slow demand for gadgets driven by inflation pressures on consumers caused the worst industry downturn in decades.

However, prices of DRAM chips – used in tech devices – and NAND flash chips – used to store data – rebounded in the December quarter, including for older chips, in a sign of an industry-wide recovery expected this year.

Mobile DRAM chip prices rose an estimated 18 to 23 per cent during the fourth quarter, while mobile NAND flash chip prices rose 10 to 15 per cent, according to data provider TrendForce.

While Samsung has repeatedly cut production since the first half of 2023 to cope with the downturn, analysts and sources said Samsung took in more supply of silicon wafers, the building blocks for semiconductors, in the fourth quarter, signalling it is gearing up to increase DRAM chip production.

Samsung was also more aggressive in selling memory chips than competitors such as SK Hynix in the fourth quarter in a bid to lower inventory, analysts said.

Rival Micron Technology forecast a quarterly revenue above market estimates last month, in a sign of a recovery in the memory chip market in 2024.

Samsung’s mobile business likely saw an operating profit of around 2.5 trillion won, according to an average of forecasts from eight analysts, as shipments of its two flagship foldable models were estimated to have fallen about 1 million units each versus the third quarter.

item.title: Podcasts gain popularity in China as one in five internet users tuned in last year, report says
item.description:
Summary：

In China during 2023, the podcast industry saw a surge in popularity, with over 220 million internet users tuning into podcasts across various genres. Young professionals working in higher-tier cities comprised a significant portion of podcast listeners. Podcast hosts also experienced financial success, earning a combined 70 million yuan on Ximalaya. Global brands recognized this growing audience, leading to podcast advertisements from companies like Coca-Cola and Cadillac. Censorship influenced Chinese podcast content, resulting in the absence of popular genres such as news and politics. Despite this, the industry continues to thrive, driven by technological advancements like generative artificial intelligence.
  • Abstract: Chinese podcast industry boom in 2023, attracting young professionals and global brands.
  • Theme: The rise of podcasts in China and its impact on various stakeholders.
  • Viewpoint: Positive outlook on the podcast industry in China, highlighting its growth, monetization opportunities, and innovations.
  • Main information: Podcast listenership demographics, revenue generation for hosts, influence of censorship on content, and the role of AI in content creation.

总结：

2023年，中国播客行业势头强劲，超过2.2亿互联网用户收听喜马拉雅上的播客，涉及31个类型。在高线城市工作的年轻专业人士是播客的主要听众群体之一。播客节目主创也在喜马拉雅上赚得盆满钵满，去年总计收入7000万元人民币。全球品牌也看中这一不断壮大的用户群体，像可口可乐和凯迪拉克等公司开始在播客投放广告。中国的网络内容审查制度对播客内容产生了影响，新闻和政治等在西方国家最受欢迎的播客类型在中国榜单上却无迹可寻。尽管如此，播客行业在生成式人工智能等技术支持下仍然蓬勃发展。
  • 摘要：2023年中国播客行业蓬勃发展，吸引年轻专业人士与全球品牌。
  • 主题：中国播客行业的崛起及其对各利益相关方的影响。
  • 观点：积极看待中国播客行业，强调其增长、变现机会和创新。
  • 主要信息：播客听众群体画像、主播收入、审查制度对内容的影响以及人工智能在内容创作中的作用。

单词：

  • revenue (n.) - /ˈrev.ə.njuː/ 收入，收益。

    原文例句：More than 22,000 podcast hosts earned a combined total of 70 million yuan (US$9.8 million) on Ximalaya last year, the company revealed in its research.

    例句讲解：该词源于拉丁语“revenire”（回来），有“归还、收益”的意思，常用来表示来自某种活动或资产的收入或收益。

  • monetization (n.) - /ˌmɑːn.ə.taɪˈzeɪ.ʃən/ 货币化。

    原文例句：Young professionals also helped Chinese podcasts attract ads from global brands, from food and beverage giant Coca-Cola to luxury US carmaker Cadillac, providing an additional monetisation channel for the industry, according to a separate report by market consultancy iResearch.

    例句讲解：该词由“monetize”（使货币化）和“-ation”（使……的过程或状态）组成，表示“使货币化”或“将某物转化为货币的过程”。

  • instance (n.) - /ˈɪns.t(ə)ns/ 实例，个例。

    原文例句：Chinese podcast preferences were partially the result of the country’s strict censorship of online content. General news and politics, two of the most popular genres among podcast listeners in Western countries, were missing from the list in China, according to Ethan Cramer-Flood, a researcher at market consultancy Insider Intelligence.“In the West, maybe news and politics rank relatively highly, whereas in China it’s just nowhere to be found because the censorship regime is so strict there,” Flood said in an online discussion last November. “So it’s [topics] like lifestyle, fashion, pet care … sports [that] are all at the top of the list because [they are] nothing remotely controversial.”

    例句讲解：该词源于拉丁语“instantia”（紧迫），意为“迫切、坚持”，常见用法有“例子、实例”等。

词组：

  • working in - 从事，在……工作。

    原文例句：The audience for its podcasts skewed towards young Chinese professionals working in the country’s higher-tier cities, Ximalaya’s research showed.

    例句讲解：这个词组由work（工作）和in（在……里面）构成，表示“在……从事某项工作”。在这个例句中，它指的是喜马拉雅的研究表明，其播客的听众主要集中在从事高线城市工作的年轻中国专业人士。

句子：

  • More than 220 million of the country’s nearly 1.1 billion internet users tuned into podcasts hosted by Ximalaya last year, across 31 genres of programmes, according to research published on Friday by the Chinese podcast service provider.- 去年，中国近11亿互联网用户中有超过2.2亿人收听了喜马拉雅播客，涵盖31种类型的节目，根据中国播客服务提供商周五发布的研究报告。

    句子分析：这是一个复合句，主句是More than 220 million of the country’s nearly 1.1 billion internet users tuned into podcasts hosted by Ximalaya last year，其中主语是More than 220 million of the country’s nearly 1.1 billion internet users，谓语是tuned into，宾语是podcasts hosted by Ximalaya。across 31 genres of programmes是一个介词短语作状语，修饰tuned into，表示收听的播客涵盖31种类型的节目。according to research published on Friday by the Chinese podcast service provider是一个介词短语作状语，修饰tuned into，表示根据中国播客服务提供商周五发布的研究报告。这个句子的意思是说，去年，中国近11亿互联网用户中有超过2.2亿人收听了喜马拉雅播客，涵盖31种类型的节目，根据中国播客服务提供商周五发布的研究报告。

语法：

  • split up into - 分成，划分为。

    原文例句：Ximalaya’s research showed the audience for its podcasts skewed towards young Chinese professionals working in the country’s higher-tier cities, with the user group aged between 24 and 40 years represented more than 60 per cent of podcast listeners in China, while those from tier-one and tier-two cities accounted for more than 65 per cent of the total audience.

    语法讲解：split up into是一个动词词组，表示“分成，划分为”。在这个例句中，它描述了喜马拉雅的研究表明其播客听众主要集中在从事高线城市工作的年轻中国专业人士，其中24至40岁年龄段的用户群占中国播客听众的60%以上，而来自一线和二线城市的用户占总听众的65%以上。

  • More than 220 million of the country’s nearly 1.1 billion internet users tuned into podcasts on Ximalaya’s platform last year, across 31 genres
  • Young professionals helped Chinese podcasts attract ads from global brands such as drinks giant Coca-Cola and luxury carmaker Cadillac

One in five internet users in China listened to a podcast last year, as the once niche sector gained popularity in 2023, according to recently published research.

More than 220 million of the country’s nearly 1.1 billion internet users tuned into podcasts hosted by Ximalaya last year, across 31 genres of programmes, according to research published on Friday by the Chinese podcast service provider.

The audience for its podcasts skewed towards young Chinese professionals working in the country’s higher-tier cities, Ximalaya’s research showed.

The user group aged between 24 and 40 years represented more than 60 per cent of podcast listeners in China, while those from tier-one and tier-two cities accounted for more than 65 per cent of the total audience.

China’s erratic regulatory moves against Big Tech must end, party paper says

Consumers in China are also increasingly more inclined to pay for quality podcast content, with more than half signing up for premium content. More than 22,000 podcast hosts earned a combined total of 70 million yuan (US$9.8 million) on Ximalaya last year, the company revealed in its research.

Young professionals also helped Chinese podcasts attract ads from global brands, from food and beverage giant Coca-Cola to luxury US carmaker Cadillac, providing an additional monetisation channel for the industry, according to a separate report by market consultancy iResearch.

Chinese users primarily tuned into podcasts during their daily commutes, with health and lifestyle, Chinese history, global politics, frontier technology, business and entertainment, as well as fantasy and thriller stories among the most popular genres on the Ximalaya platform.

Chinese podcast preferences were partially the result of the country’s strict censorship of online content. General news and politics, two of the most popular genres among podcast listeners in Western countries, were missing from the list in China, according to Ethan Cramer-Flood, a researcher at market consultancy Insider Intelligence.

“In the West, maybe news and politics rank relatively highly, whereas in China it’s just nowhere to be found because the censorship regime is so strict there,” Flood said in an online discussion last November. “So it’s [topics] like lifestyle, fashion, pet care … sports [that] are all at the top of the list because [they are] nothing remotely controversial.”

Still, Chinese podcasts are flourishing despite the country’s online content crackdown. In 2023, Ximalaya’s platform hosted 5.2 million more podcast episodes than the year before.

The podcast industry in China is also riding the wave of generative artificial intelligence (AI), which increases efficiency and helps with content creation, thanks to a suite of AI-powered audio tools Ximalaya launched last year.

item.title: Chinese EV maker Geely introduces first pure electric Galaxy model, to woo mainstream buyers from BYD, foreign brands
item.description:
Summary：

  • 吉利汽车集团推出其大众品牌Galaxy旗下的纯电动轿车E8，以应对日益激烈的市场竞争，与比亚迪畅销车型展开竞争。
  • E8的基本版售175,800元（约合24,752美元），比比亚迪的汉电动汽车低34,000元；E8的特点包括45英寸屏幕、高通骁龙8295芯片、智能语音控制系统等。
  • E8是吉利汽车集团基于SEA平台打造的首款纯电动汽车，预计将于2025年推出总共7款车型；在竞争激烈的市场环境下，新一轮价格战正在进行，比亚迪、小鹏等头部玩家纷纷推出优惠活动以吸引消费者。

Chinese summary：

  • 吉利汽车集团推出其大众品牌Galaxy旗下的纯电动轿车E8，以应对日益激烈的市场竞争，与比亚迪畅销车型展开竞争。
  • E8的基本版售175,800元（约合24,752美元），比比亚迪的汉电动汽车低34,000元；E8的特点包括45英寸屏幕、高通骁龙8295芯片、智能语音控制系统等。
  • E8是吉利汽车集团基于SEA平台打造的首款纯电动汽车，预计将于2025年推出总共7款车型；在竞争激烈的市场环境下，新一轮价格战正在进行，比亚迪、小鹏等头部玩家纷纷推出优惠活动以吸引消费者。

单词：

  • affordability (n.) - /əˌfɔːdəˈbɪləti/ 负担得起，可负担性。

    原文例句：The cars will be more affordable for mainland consumers than the company’s Zeekr-branded EVs, which compete against premium models built by companies like Tesla, Gan said.

    例句讲解：这个单词是由afford（负担得起）和-ability（能力，可行性）构成的，表示“负担得起的状况，可负担性”。在这个例句中，它指的是吉利汽车集团的Galaxy品牌汽车将比该公司竞争高端电动汽车市场（如特斯拉）的Zeekr品牌更加经济实惠。

  • connectivity (n.) - /kəˈnɛktɪvəti/ 连接，连通性。

    原文例句：Geely Automobile Group is partnering with China Mobile to launch a new energy vehicle platform that will provide better connectivity and other services for car owners.

    例句讲解：这个单词是由connect（连接）和-ivity（性，状态）构成的，表示“连接的状态或程度，连通性”。在这个例句中，它指的是吉利汽车集团与中国移动合作推出新能源汽车平台，将为车主提供更好的连接和其他服务。

词组：

  • on account of - 因为。

    原文例句：The deposit will be refunded on account of the theft.

    例句讲解：这个词组是由on（在……方面），account（原因，理由）和of（因为）构成的，表示“因为，由于”。在这个例句中，它表示押金将因为盗窃行为而被退还。

句子：

  • The E8 is also its first full-electric car, following two plug-in hybrid vehicles – the L7 sport-utility vehicle and the L6 sedan – launched in 2023. - E8 也是其第一款纯电动汽车，继 2023 年推出的两款插电式混合动力汽车 L7 运动型多用途车和 L6 轿车之后。

    句子分析：这是一个复合句，主句是E8 is also its first full-electric car，其中主语是E8，谓语是is，宾语是first full-electric car。following two plug-in hybrid vehicles – the L7 sport-utility vehicle and the L6 sedan – launched in 2023是一个现在分词短语作状语，修饰主句，表示E8是继2023年推出的两款分别是L7和L6的插电式混合动力汽车之后的，强调E8是第一款纯电动汽车的推出时间和先后顺序。这个句子的意思是说，E8是吉利汽车集团的首款纯电动汽车，在2023年推出两款插电式混合动力汽车——L7运动型多用途车和L6轿车之后。

语法：

  • 比较级的用法 - 表示比较，相当于“比……更”。

    原文例句：The E8 features a 45-inch screen supplied by display panel ­manufacturer BOE Technology, the biggest in a Chinese-made smart vehicle. - E8 配备了由显示面板制造商京东方科技提供的一块 45 英寸屏幕，是国产智能汽车中最大的。

    语法讲解：这是一个比较级的用法，由the biggest in a Chinese-made smart vehicle构成，形容词biggest表示“最大的”，in a Chinese-made smart vehicle是对smart vehicle的修饰，表示“在国产智能汽车中”。这个句子的意思是说，E8配备了一块由京东方科技提供的45英寸屏幕，这是国产智能汽车中最大的。

  • 过去式的用法 - 表示过去发生的动词

    原文例句：Geely launched its Galaxy brand in 2023. - 吉利于 2023 年推出其 Galaxy 品牌。

    语法讲解：这是一个过去式的用法，由launched构成，表示吉利在2023年推出了其Galaxy品牌。过去式的形成规则是：规则动词在词尾加-ed或-d，不规则动词根据变音规则变化。这个句子的意思是说，吉利在2023年推出了其Galaxy品牌。

  • The Galaxy E8 sells for almost about US$25,000, nearly US$5,000 less than BYD’s Han model
  • Geely plans to offer seven models under the affordable Galaxy brand by 2025, while its Zeekr brand targets more affluent buyers

Geely Automobile Group, one of China’s largest private carmakers, has launched a pure electric sedan under its mass-market brand Galaxy to take on BYD’s bestselling models amid intensified competition.

The basic edition of the E8, with a driving range of 550 kilometres, sells for 175,800 yuan (US$24,752), 34,000 yuan lower than the Han electric vehicle (EV) built by BYD, which has a range of 506km.

Hangzhou-based Geely will begin delivering the Class B sedan in February, hoping to target budget-sensitive mainland motorists, according to the company’s CEO Gan Jiayue.

“In terms of safety, design, performance and intelligence, E8 proves to be superior to all blockbuster models,” he said during a media briefing after a launch ceremony on Friday. “We expect it to be an ideal model to replace both existing petrol and electric cars.”

Geely lowered the price of the model by 12,200 yuan from its 188,000 yuan pricing on December 16 when presales started.

Based on the company’s Sustainable Experience Architecture (SEA), the E8 is also its first full-electric car, following two plug-in hybrid vehicles – the L7 sport-utility vehicle and the L6 sedan – launched in 2023.

The company plans to manufacture and sell a total of seven models under the Galaxy brand by 2025. The cars will be more affordable for mainland consumers than the company’s Zeekr-branded EVs, which compete against premium models built by companies like Tesla, Gan said.

Short sellers target BYD, world’s top EV maker, as rivalry intensifies

Its parent, Zhejiang Geely Holding Group, also owns marquees including Volvo, Lotus and Lynk. Geely Holding has a nearly 6 per cent share of mainland China’s EV market.

The E8 uses a Qualcomm Snapdragon 8295 chip to support its intelligent features such as voice-activated controls. A 45-inch screen, the biggest in a Chinese-made smart vehicle, is supplied by display panel ­manufacturer BOE Technology.

At present, the Class B sedan category in China is dominated by petrol-powered models from foreign carmakers such as Volkswagen and Toyota.

China’s BYD overtakes Tesla as largest maker of pure-electric vehicles

BYD, the world’s largest EV maker, backed by Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway, delivered a total of 228,383 Han sedans to Chinese customers in 2023, up 59 per cent on year.

Sales of battery-powered vehicles in mainland China are seen as growing 20 per cent year on year in 2024, according to a Fitch Ratings’ report in November, slowing from a 37 per cent rise last year, according to the China Passenger Car Association.

China is the world’s largest automotive and EV market, with sales of electric cars accounting for about 60 per cent of the global total. But only a few makers, including BYD and Li Auto, are profitable.

A new round of price cuts is in effect, with top players like BYD and Xpeng offering discounts to lure buyers.

In November, Geely’s parent company formed a partnership with Shanghai-based Nio, a premium EV maker, to promote battery swapping technology as the two companies try to overcome the problem of inadequate charging infrastructure.

Battery-swapping technology allows owners of electric cars to quickly exchange a spent battery pack for a fully charged one.

item.title: Huawei teardown shows 5-nm laptop chip made in Taiwan, not China
item.description:
English summary：

  • Huawei's Qingyun L540 laptop contains a 5nm chip manufactured by TSMC in 2020, around the time of the US sanctions that cut off Huawei's access to TSMC's chips.
  • Rumors of Huawei's domestic chipmaking partner SMIC achieving a major technological breakthrough in chip manufacturing were debunked when a teardown of the device revealed the use of a TSMC 5nm chip.
  • Huawei's Mate 60 Pro smartphone, released last August, featured a 7nm chip manufactured by SMIC, indicating China's progress in chip manufacturing despite US sanctions.
  • Huawei's successful product launches and ability to procure chips, despite the challenges posed by US sanctions, underscore its resilience and efforts to reduce dependence on Western technologies.
  • Chinese consumers' strong demand for the Mate 60 Pro helped Huawei reach the symbolic revenue threshold of $100 billion, challenging Apple's dominance in the smartphone market.
  • Huawei's stockpiling of vital semiconductors since 2019, as well as its investments in chip research and its network of suppliers, have played a crucial role in its ability to navigate the ongoing trade restrictions.

中文总结：

  • 华为清云L540笔记本搭载台积电在2020年制造的5纳米芯片，当时正值美国制裁切断华为与台积电的芯片供应。
  • 此前有传闻称，华为的国内芯片制造合作伙伴中芯国际在芯片制造方面取得重大技术突破，但拆解后发现该设备使用了台积电5纳米芯片，该传闻不攻自破。
  • 去年8月，华为推出的Mate 60 Pro智能手机搭载了由中芯国际制造的7纳米芯片，表明中国在芯片制造方面取得了进展，尽管面临美国制裁。
  • 尽管面临美国制裁，华为仍然取得了较好的产品发布成果并能够采购到芯片，这凸显其韧性和减少对西方技术依赖的努力。
  • 中国消费者对Mate 60 Pro的强劲需求帮助华为达到1000亿美元的象征性收入门槛，挑战了苹果在智能手机市场的主导地位。
  • 华为自2019年以来一直囤积重要的半导体，并投资芯片研发和供应商网络，这些因素在其规避持续的贸易限制中发挥了关键作用。

单词：

  • cut off - 切断，断绝。

    原文例句：US sanctions cut off Huawei’s access to the chip maker

    例句讲解：cut off是cut的过去分词，表示“切断，断绝”。在这个例句中，它表示美国制裁切断了华为与芯片制造商的联系。

  • teardown - 拆卸，拆解。

    原文例句：A teardown of the device showed, quashing talk of another Chinese technological breakthrough.

    例句讲解：teardown是tear down的ing形式，表示“拆卸，拆解”。在这个例句中，它表示拆解该设备，从而证实了中国技术突破的传言不成立。

  • counter - 反对，抵消。

    原文例句：That counters speculation that Huawei’s mainland Chinese chipmaking partner, Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp (SMIC), may have achieved a major leap in fabrication technique.

    例句讲解：counter是动词，表示“反对，抵消”。在这个例句中，它表示这反驳了猜测，即华为的中国大陆芯片制造合作伙伴中芯国际可能在制造工艺方面取得了重大突破。

词组：

  • take a step further - 更进一步。

    原文例句： Huawei’s Mate 60 smartphone, released last August, featured a 7nm chip manufactured by Shanghai-based SMIC, indicating China's progress in chip manufacturing despite US sanctions.

    例句讲解：take a step further是动词词组，表示“更进一步”。在这个例句中，它表示中国在芯片制造方面取得了进展，尽管面临美国制裁。

  • The Qingyun L540 notebook contains a 5-nm chip made by TSMC in 2020, around the time US sanctions cut off Huawei’s access to the chip maker
  • Huawei caused a stir in the US and China last August when it released a smartphone with a 7-nm processor made by Shanghai-based SMIC

Huawei Technologies’ newest laptop runs on a chip made by Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC), a teardown of the device showed, quashing talk of another Chinese technological breakthrough.

The Qingyun L540 notebook contains a 5-nanometre chip made by the Taiwanese company in 2020, around the time US sanctions cut off Huawei’s access to the chip maker, research firm TechInsights found after dismantling the device for Bloomberg News. That counters speculation that Huawei’s mainland Chinese chipmaking partner, Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp (SMIC), may have achieved a major leap in fabrication technique.

Huawei caused a stir in the US and China last August when it released a smartphone with a 7-nm processor made by Shanghai-based SMIC. A teardown by the Canada-based research outfit for Bloomberg News showed the Mate 60 Pro’s chip was only a few years behind the cutting edge, a feat that US trade curbs were meant to prevent. That revelation spurred celebration across the Chinese tech scene, and a debate in the US about the effectiveness of sanctions.

Huawei sees 9 per cent sales growth in 2023, boosted by Mate 60 Pro 5G comeback

In the latest teardown, TechInsights discovered a Kirin 9006C processor fabricated via TSMC’s 5-nm method, which was assembled and packaged around the third quarter of 2020. Industry experts had previously speculated that SMIC achieved that milestone by developing workarounds to US sanctions, which would have marked a second technological triumph for the Chinese national champion in the span of months.

Representatives for Huawei and TSMC did not provide comment when reached by Bloomberg News.

The advances encapsulated in the Mate 60 smartphone in 2023 cemented Huawei’s role as the standard-bearer for Chinese efforts to wean itself off Western technologies and create domestic alternatives. Chinese consumers snapped up the smartphone in the final quarter, helping the company regain the symbolically important US$100 billion revenue threshold – eroding Apple’s iPhone dominance along the way.

A foray into 5-nm territory would have represented a big leap for the Shenzhen conglomerate, bringing it closer to the most-advanced processes currently in use, mostly centred around 3-nm nodes. Before TSMC cut off ties with Huawei, it was supplying chips as advanced as 5-nm to the Chinese firm.

It is unclear how Huawei managed to procure a three-year-old processor, though the Chinese company has been stockpiling vital semiconductors since the US began cutting off its access to components and gear globally. While Huawei has been on Washington’s Entity List since 2019, it was only in 2020 that TSMC stopped taking orders from Huawei to comply with elevated US trade restrictions.

Huawei has since sunk billions into chip research and stockpiling in past years, while also building a domestic network of suppliers and manufacturing partners, in some cases with government backing.

The L540 is the latest in a line of laptops that Huawei began selling around 2016, when the then-networking leader developed ambitions to get into mobile and computing devices and round out its offerings.

Its emergence coincides with a growing call from Beijing to replace foreign technology in sensitive environments, from mandates to stop using iPhones in the workplace to replacing Dell and HP computers.

Some online retailers touted that the new laptop was designed specifically to comply with recent, stringent requirements in China on data security across sensitive government organs. Huawei’s official site highlights the device’s security features, but did not go into that detail.
